children.comments:
This instance requires the inner type to be a `Monad`, because the `Apply`
instance requires it.
children.title: <anonymous>

This instance requires the inner type to be a `Monad`, because the `Apply`
instance requires it.

declarations.comments:
`Select` is an abstraction that sits between `Apply` and `Bind`.

Instances must satisfy the following law:
- Associativity:
```purescript
  x <*? (y <*? z) = ((map Right <$> x) <*? (f <$> y)) <*? uncurry z
  where
  f (Left y) x = Tuple y x
  f (Right y) x = y x
```
declarations.title: Select

declarations.comments: `select` implemented in terms of `bind` and `pure`
declarations.title: selectM

declarations.comments:
`select` implemented in terms of `sequence`. With this implementation,
depending on the `Either` in the first argument, the first or the second
effect will be executed, but never both. `Traversable` allows us to
inspect the `Either` in the first parameter without including its effect
in the result. This implementation is well suited for array-like
traversables. (i.e. potentially containing more than one element)
declarations.title: selectTM

declarations.comments:
`select` implemented in terms of `sequence` and `apply`. This
implementation uses `apply` to keep the effects of the first parameter
when it is a `Left`, unlike `selectTM`. This implementation is well suited
for tuple-like traversables (i.e. containing one or fewer elements)
declarations.title: selectTS

declarations.comments: `select` implemented in terms of `apply` (both effects are always executed)
declarations.title: selectA

declarations.comments: `apply` implemented in terms of `select`
declarations.title: applyS

declarations.comments: Execute the second action if the first action returns true
declarations.title: whenS

declarations.comments: Execute the second action if the first action returns false
declarations.title: unlessS

declarations.comments:
Execute either the second or the third action, depending on the result of
the first
declarations.title: branch

declarations.comments: If the first action is true, execute the second action, otherwise the third
declarations.title: ifS

declarations.comments: Short-circuiting or
declarations.title: orS

declarations.comments: Short-circuiting and
declarations.title: andS

declarations.comments: Short-circuiting any
declarations.title: any1S

declarations.comments: Short-circuiting all
declarations.title: all1S

declarations.comments: If the second action is `Nothing`, run and return the first
declarations.title: fromMaybeS

declarations.comments: Repeat an action until it returns true
declarations.title: whileS

declarations.comments:
This typeclass extends `Select` with an identity (`pure`).
`Selective` is an abstraction that sits between `Applicative` and `Monad`.

Instances must satisfy the following laws:
- Identity: `x <*? pure identity = either identity identity <$> x`
- Distributivity: `pure x <*? (y *> z) = (pure x <*? y) *> (pure x <*? z)`
- Monad subclass (if `f` is a `Monad`): `select = selectM`
declarations.title: Selective

declarations.comments: Short-circuiting any
declarations.title: anyS

declarations.comments: Short-circuiting all
declarations.title: allS

children.comments:
"Lifts" the inner type's selective instance into the outer via `lift2`.
The outer effect will always be executed.
children.title: <anonymous>

declarations.comments:
This newtype provides a `Select` instance for `Compose`.
It "lifts" the `Selective` `g` into the `Applicative` `f`. In other words,
it composes an outer `Applicative` and an inner `Selective`.
declarations.title: ComposeI

children.comments:
This newtype provides a `Select` instance for `Compose`. It "lifts" the
`Traversable` `g` into the `Selective` `f`.

This instance works best when the traversable's "effect" is
failure/nondeterminism, like `Array` or `Maybe`. It doesn't work too well
in other cases, for example if `g`is `Tuple`, then if the first parameter
contains a `Left` (requiring use of the second parameter), *only* the
second parameter's `fst` value actually ends up in the result. See
`ComposeT` for an instance that works better for types like `Tuple`.
children.title: <anonymous>

declarations.comments:
This newtype provides a `Select` instance for `Compose`.
It "lifts" the `Traversable` `g` into the `Selective` `f`. `ComposeTM` does
this in a way that works well when the `g`/inner type is like `Array` or
`Maybe`, whose "effect" just involves the amount of elements, and doesn't
store any extra data alongside elements, like `Tuple` does. More details
in the documentation for the `Select` instance. See also `ComposeT` for an
alternate implementation that's better suited for tuples.
declarations.title: ComposeTM

children.comments:
This newtype provides a `Select` instance for `Compose`. It "lifts" the
`Traversable` `g` into the `Selective` `f`.

This instance works best when the traversable type never has more than one
"slot", like `Maybe` or `Tuple`. If `g` does have more than one slot, like
`Array`, one `Left` in the first argument to `select` makes it as if every
element was that specific `Left`, replacing any `Right`s and subsequent
`Left`s. See `ComposeTM` for an instance that works better with types like
`Array`.
children.title: <anonymous>

declarations.comments:
This newtype provides a `Select` instance for `Compose`.
It "lifts" the `Traversable` `g` into the `Selective` `f`. `ComposeTS` does
this in a way that works well when the `g`/inner type is like `Tuple` or
`Maybe`, never containing more than one `a`. More details in the
documentation for the `Select` instance. See `ComposeTM` for a different
implementation that's better suited for arrays.
declarations.title: ComposeTS

declarations.comments: A simple free `Selective`.
declarations.title: FreeS

declarations.comments: Lift a computation into the free `Selective`.
declarations.title: liftF

declarations.comments: Run a free computation.
declarations.title: runFree

declarations.comments: Run a free computation in an applicative via `SelectA`
declarations.title: runFreeA

declarations.comments: Run a free computation in a monad via `SelectM`
declarations.title: runFreeM

declarations.comments: Run a free computation in a traversable via `SelectTS`
declarations.title: runFreeTS

declarations.comments: Run a free computation in a traversable via `SelectTM`
declarations.title: runFreeTM

declarations.comments: Fold together every possible effect.
declarations.title: foldOver

declarations.comments: Collect every possible effect into an `Array`.
declarations.title: effectsOver

declarations.comments: Count how many possible effects there are.
declarations.title: countOver

declarations.comments: Fold together every required effect.
declarations.title: foldUnder

declarations.comments: Collect every required effect into an `Array`.
declarations.title: effectsUnder

declarations.comments: Count how many required effects there are.
declarations.title: countUnder

declarations.comments: Extract a pure value if there are no effects.
declarations.title: getPure

declarations.comments: Collects optional effects. See also `Under`.
declarations.title: Over

declarations.comments: Has a `Select` instance where `select` is implemented in terms of `apply`
declarations.title: SelectA

declarations.comments: Has a `Select` instance where `select` is implemented in terms of `bind`
declarations.title: SelectM

children.comments:
`Select` implemented in terms of `sequence`. With this implementation,
depending on the `Either` in the first argument, the first or the second
effect will be executed, but never both. `Traversable` allows us to
inspect the `Either` in the first parameter without including its effect
in the result. This implementation is well suited for array-like
traversables. (i.e. potentially containing more than one element).
children.title: <anonymous>

declarations.comments:
Has a `Select` instance where `select` is implemented in terms of
`sequence`. See also `SelectTS`.
declarations.title: SelectTM

children.comments:
`Select` implemented in terms of `sequence` and `apply`. This
implementation uses `apply` to keep the effects of the first parameter
when it is a `Left`, unlike `SelectTM`. This implementation is well suited
for tuple-like traversables (i.e. containing one or fewer elements)
children.title: <anonymous>

declarations.comments:
Has a `Select` instance where `select` is implemented in terms of
`sequence`. See also `SelectTM`
declarations.title: SelectTS

declarations.comments: Ignores optional effects. See also `Over`.
declarations.title: Under

declarations.comments: Ignores errors in not-chosen branches.
declarations.title: Validation
